greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Satisfies A^3 = BINOMIAL(A^2).
comment: In general, if A^n = BINOMIAL(A^(n-1)), then for all integer m>0 there exists an integer sequence B such that B^d = BINOMIAL(A^m) where d=gcd(m+1,n). Also, coefficients of A(k*x)^n = k-th binomial transform of coefficients in A(k*x)^(n-1) for all k>0.
link: Vaclav Kotesovec, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..390
formula: O.g.f. A(x) = exp( Sum_{n >= 1} b(n)*x^n/n ), where b(n) = Sum_{k = 1..n} k!*Stirling2(n,k)*2^(k-1) = A050351(n) = 1/2*A004123(n+1) for n >= 1. - _Peter Bala_, May 26 2015
mathematica: Do[A[x_] = Sum[a[k] x^k, {k, 0, n}] /. sol; eq = CoefficientList[A[x]^3 - A[x/(1 - x)]^2/(1 - x) + O[x]^(n + 1), x] == 0 /. sol; sol = sol ~Join~ Solve[eq][[1]], {n, 1, nmax}];
results.author: _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 26 2003
